user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketConnect_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SocketConnect_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_SockAddr_t *Addr, int32 timeout)
{
    int32                           return_code;
    int                             os_status;
    int                             sockopt;
    socklen_t                       slen;
    uint32                          operation;
    const struct sockaddr *         sa;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    sa = (const struct sockaddr *)&Addr->AddrData;
    switch (sa->sa_family)
    {
        case AF_INET:
            slen = sizeof(struct sockaddr_in);
            break;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
        case AF_INET6:
            slen = sizeof(struct sockaddr_in6);
            break;
#endif
        default:
            slen = 0;
            break;
    }

    if (slen != Addr->ActualLength)
    {
        return_code = OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS;
    }
    else
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
        os_status   = connect(impl->fd, sa, slen);
        if (os_status < 0)
        {
            if (errno != EINPROGRESS)
            {
                OS_DEBUG("connect: %s\n", strerror(errno));
                return_code = OS_ERROR;
            }
            else
            {
                /*
                 * If the socket was created in nonblocking mode (O_NONBLOCK flag) then the connect
                 * runs in the background and connect() returns EINPROGRESS.  In this case we still
                 * want to provide the "normal" (blocking) semantics to the calling app, such that
                 * when OS_SocketConnect() returns, the socket is ready for use.
                 *
                 * To provide consistent behavior to calling apps, this does a select() to wait
                 * for the socket to become writable, meaning that the remote side is connected.
                 *
                 * An important point here is that the calling app can control the timeout.  If the
                 * normal/blocking connect() was used, the OS/IP stack controls the timeout, and it
                 * can be quite long.
                 */
                operation = OS_STREAM_STATE_WRITABLE;
                if (impl->selectable)
                {
                    return_code = OS_SelectSingle_Impl(token, &operation, timeout);
                }
                if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
                {
                    if ((operation & OS_STREAM_STATE_WRITABLE) == 0)
                    {
                        return_code = OS_ERROR_TIMEOUT;
                    }
                    else
                    {
                        /*
                         * The SO_ERROR socket flag should also read back zero.
                         * If not zero, something went wrong during connect
                         */
                        sockopt   = 0;
                        slen      = sizeof(sockopt);
                        os_status = getsockopt(impl->fd, SOL_SOCKET, SO_ERROR, &sockopt, &slen);
                        if (os_status < 0 || sockopt != 0)
                        {
                            return_code = OS_ERROR;
                        }
                    }
                }
            }
        }
    }
    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketConnect_Impl:
extern OS_impl_file_internal_record_t OS_impl_filehandle_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct
{
    int  fd;
    bool selectable;
} OS_impl_file_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    size_t            ActualLength; /**< @brief Length of the actual address data */
    OS_SockAddrData_t AddrData;     /**< @brief Abstract Address data */
} OS_SockAddr_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragments need investigation for Rule 17.8. Reasoning:
- The function parameters are: const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_SockAddr_t *Addr, int32 timeout.
- There are no assignments to the parameter variables (no occurrences of token = ..., Addr = ..., or timeout = ...). The parameters are only read or dereferenced.
- The pointer parameters are not reassigned. The local pointer variable sa is assigned the address of Addr->AddrData, but this assigns to a local variable (sa), not to the parameter Addr itself; it does not modify the pointer parameter.
- The objects referred to by the pointer parameters are only read (e.g., *token used to index table, Addr->ActualLength read); there is no modification of *token or contents of *Addr.
- Calls that take addresses (e.g., &operation, &sockopt, &slen) use local variables, not function parameters.

Therefore, no fragments in this function violate the requirement that function parameters shall not be modified.
